title: Roman Vs. Italic
content:
Recently, after learning of the roots of italic, I have been paying more attention to them and how it seems that majiscules in Italic sets never really seem to fit. The more I look at them, the uppercase is basically just angled. I realize they have been redrawn for the set, but does anyone else sense that disconnect between the upper and lowercase in Italic sets ?

 [‹ Plaka Joke](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/typophile.com/node/13165 "Go to previous forum topic") [Photoshop Users Headline ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/typophile.com/node/13099 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Eric_West

comments.content:
Historically the caps were actually upright romans.  
Look at samples of [Arrighi’s specimen of italics.](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/www.columbia.edu/cu/lweb/data/indiv/rare/type-exhibit/2rvi/rvi.htm)

————————————————————  
Yes, I’m old, but I’m back in style!

Eric, yes! And the disconnect is actually an amplification of the disconnect between lc and UC in basic Roman! A “solution” I myself have used in italic caps: semi-serifs (see Patria).

But deeper and more drastic solution would be to delve into uncials...

hhp
As I pondered my question after I posted today, would a Script-esque Uppercase, more condensed, obviously specifically drawn for the lc italics be a solution. I’m going to do some experiments.

Eric, for Arrighi’s calligraphy his caps were quite different (and beautiful) than the roman used for italic type and might give you at least a historic reference.

Sample pages from [Arrighi’s Operina,](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/www.acmedigital.net/jiansabu/arrighi.htm) c. 1522 (published 1524)  
 [http://www.acmedigital.net/jiansabu/arrighi.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/www.acmedigital.net/jiansabu/arrighi.htm "http://www.acmedigital.net/jiansabu/arrighi.htm")

———————————————————-  
Yes, I’m old, but not as old as Arrighi!
Norbert, that sample is amazing. Has anyone attempted a digital interpretation of Arrighi’s calligraphy? Looks like a prime candidate to me...
A digital version of Arrighi’s calligraphy with auto ligatures like in Underware’s Bello would be soooooooo nice. With that and Zapfino, pens are in for extinction!

I believe [James Grieshaber](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/typophile.com/wiki/James%252BGrieshaber) may be working on an OT version of [Operina](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/www.p22.com/ihof/operinaset.html). If it’s anything like [Cezanne Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013184335/http:/www.p22.com/products/cezannepro.html), then expect very cool OT features.

I was just about to suggest Operina from P22, when I scrolled a little further and voila, Paul had already done it.

Operina Opentype??? Please don’t tease, Paul!
